comments:
MGMT 230 integrates the material introduced in business fundamental courses and applies it to the design and evaluation of new ventures. The purpose of this course is to explore the many dimensions of new venture creation and growth and to foster innovation and new business formations in independent and corporate settings. The course addresses both a theoretical perspective on venture initiation and the application of writing an actual business plan.
Students commented that a lot of group work was required for this course, and that sometimes there are overlapping sections within the requirements,” which “makes it very difficult to structure” some of the assignments. As a consequence of the “vague” rubrics of the assignments, a significant group of students commented that grading felt “arbitrary.”

Most students commented that  Professor Wry’s teachings did not meet expectations. Specifically, several students said that he “relied too much on textbook-style teaching, when it's real-world stories that are clearly the best for entrepreneurship.”  Other students commented that Professor Wry’s teaching of MGMT 230 was biased by his experience as a “failed entrepreneur.” Nevertheless, most students felt that Professor Wry “enjoyed teaching the class,” was “very accessible,” “engaging,” and “funny.”

Overall, Students commented that MGMT 230 is a “project-based course” that can be fairly “time intensive.” The prerequisites for this course include the completion of all business fundamental courses and second semester sophomore standing. Though not required, it is also highly recommended that students have mastered the concepts of business policy.
